definition:
Let $R$ be a ring. A [*free module*]{} over $R$ is a direct sum of
copies of $R$.

Similarly, as an abelian group is simply a module over $\Bbb{Z}$, a
[*free abelian group*]{} is a direct sum of copies of $\Bbb{Z}$.

This is equivalent to saying that the module has a [*free basis*]{},
i.e. a set of elements with the property that every element of the
module can be uniquely expressed as an linear combination over $R$ of
elements of the free basis.

Every free module is also a projective module, as well as a flat module.
